docs.lead_paragraph: The expansion of Medicaid in the health care law, if it is upheld, would greatly increase the number of people served — and add to the program’s costs.

headline.seo: In Health Care Ruling, Vast Implications for Medicaid
headline.main: In Health Care Ruling, Vast Implications for Medicaid
headline.print_headline: In Health Care Ruling, Vast Implications for Medicaid

docs.abstract: Supreme Court ruling on the new health care law will have vast implications for Medicaid and the 250,000 people who will benefit from the expansion of the program in Arkansas alone; state officials everywhere worry about the costs associated with expanding Medicaid programs, and one of the aspects of the law that the Supreme Court is deliberating on is the ability of Congress to attach conditions to money it distributes to states.
docs.snippet: The expansion of Medicaid in the health care law, if it is upheld, would greatly increase the number of people served — and add to the program’s costs.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: With a crucial decision on President Obama’s health care law due soon, a book by Supreme Court Justice, Antonin Scalia, on how he interprets law is well-timed.

headline.seo: In Scalia’s New Book, Hints of Health Ruling
headline.main: Hints in New Scalia Book of Views on Health Law
headline.print_headline: Hints in New Scalia Book Of Views on Health Law

docs.abstract: Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia's new book Reading Law: The Interpretation of Legal Texts is studded with telling asides and intimations about past and future decisions, and could shed some light on the upcoming Supreme Court decision on the health care law.
docs.snippet: With a crucial decision on President Obama’s health care law due soon, a book by Supreme Court Justice, Antonin Scalia, on how he interprets law is well-timed.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: This election is about whether we try to work within the existing governing model or render it obsolete to build something fresh.
docs.abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column explains that Republicans are convinced that the current governing model is obsolete and is on the verge of collapse, as opposed to Democrats, who think the governing model merely needs to be rebalanced; contends that these two opposing philosophies are illustrated by how Pres Obama and Mitt Romney are campaigning; posits that the likely collapse of the European project will profoundly influence which perception voters buy.
docs.snippet: This election is about whether we try to work within the existing governing model or render it obsolete to build something fresh.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama makes his case against Mitt Romney’s tried and discredited economic policies.
docs.abstract: Editorial warns Pres Obama that he has yet to make a succinct case for why voters should choose him over his opponent Mitt Romney, as illustrated by his overlong economic policy speech to his supporters in Cleveland; holds that Obama is running out of time to make the vital point that Romney is trying to resurrect failed Bush-era economic policies.
docs.snippet: President Obama makes his case against Mitt Romney’s tried and discredited economic policies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Independent drugstores are raising questions about the state’s effort to save tens of millions of dollars by rolling pharmacies into Medicaid managed care.

headline.seo: Texas Medicaid Overhaul Means Pain for Some Pharmacists
headline.main: For Some Druggists, Medicaid Changes Mean Pain
headline.print_headline: For Some Druggists, Medicaid Changes Mean Pain

docs.snippet: Independent drugstores are raising questions about the state’s effort to save tens of millions of dollars by rolling pharmacies into Medicaid managed care.

docs.lead_paragraph: If the measure is not thrown out, House Republicans plan to force a repeal vote, while top officials at the White House are projecting confidence that the justices will rule in their favor.

headline.seo: Parties Strategize for Dealing With Supreme Court Decision on Health Care
headline.main: With Justices Set to Rule on Health Law, 2 Parties Strategize
headline.print_headline: Parties Plan Next Move Once Supreme Court Rules on Health Care

docs.abstract: House Republicans plan to force a vote to repeal Pres Obama's new health care law should the Supreme Court decide to uphold it; move would reinforce the party's deep opposition to the law, which has become central to their political identity; Obama's Democratic allies are also preparing their response to a potentially unfavorable decision, gearing up to press Republicans on the issue of the uninsured.
docs.snippet: If the measure is not thrown out, House Republicans plan to force a repeal vote, while top officials at the White House are projecting confidence that the justices will rule in their favor.

byline.original: By JONATHAN WEISMAN and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is expected to issue a decision this month on President Obama's 2010 health care law. The court is considering a series of questions to determine whether the law, or parts of it, will survive. 1. Is it too soon to consider this case?
docs.abstract: Diagram illustrates a series of questions the Supreme Court will use when it determines whether Pres Obama's health care law, or parts of it, will survive. Diagram (M)
